Structure

Before analysing the contents of a .Net assembly, it might be convinient to know what to expect, i.e., what are the components inside it. The, very high-level, content of a .Net library are:

  • Assembly
    • Collection of Referenced Assembly(ies)
    • Collection of Module(s), at least one
  • Module
    • Collection of Field(s)
    • Collection of Method(s)
    • Collection of Type(s)
  • Type
    • Collection of Field(s)
    • Collection of Method(s)
    • Collection of Property(ies)
    • Collection of Event(s)

There is, obviously, loads more data in each component. For instance, if the library is an executable the assembly must have an entry point property defined. This, for now, will suffice our scope and purpose.
